title: PASS
name: pass
blurb: Pass is the title of my ongoing novel (realistic fiction).  It follows Conor Moreton, a seventh grader with a penchant for climbing on things, as he deals with a sudden alienation from his best friend and a teacher with strange ideas and stranger methods.  "On superheroes, parkour, and the meaning of friendship..."

title: INFLECTION POINT
name: camp
blurb: This is the curriculum for a two-week rationality camp developed for the middle-grades age group.  Its intent is to lay the groundwork for lifelong growth as an agent for positive change, providing underchallenged kids and teens with an introduction to the core concepts of logic, psychology, decision theory, epistemology, and heroic responsibility.

title: R!ANIMORPHS: THE RECKONING
name: animorphs
blurb: This is a fanfiction, inspired by 'Harry Potter and the Methods of Rationality' and based on the beloved teen sci-fi series 'Animorphs.'  In this reimagining, the rules of the universe have been made internally consistent, and both heroes and villains act with rational self-interest, moving toward victory as quickly and intelligently as they can.

title: MODERATING LESSWRONG
name: LESSWRONG
blurb: LessWrong is a web archive and discussion forum for improving human rationality. In this post, I lay out a philosophy of moderation that differs significantly from that on the actual site.

title: OPEN PROBLEMS IN GROUP RATIONALITY
name: grouprat
blurb: An attempt to isolate specific, tractable problems in the domain of understanding and improving collaboration and decisionmaking in humans.

title: BUCKETS AND BAYES
name: buckets-bayes-bf61dd4163d9
blurb: An exploration of the concept of 'bucket errors,' along with an introduction to simple Bayesian reasoning and how it can help prevent them.

title: GOODHART'S IMPERIUS
name: goodhart
blurb: A look into the way the human brain conditions itself according to implicit models derived from aggregated experience, and how this can go horribly, horribly wrong.

title: 'FOCUSING' FOR SKEPTICS
name: FOCUSING
blurb: An introduction to a variant of Eugene Gendlin's 'Focusing' technique, which is an interface for drawing explicit information out of one's implicit models and subconscious feelings by attending to small changes in one's physiological sensations.

title: IN DEFENSE OF PUNCH BUG
name: punchbug
blurb: A critique of a certain mindset I'm calling 'social ownership of micro,' and a gesture in the direction of an alternative based on the children's game 'punch bug.'

title: THE MTG COLOR WHEEL
name: colorwheel
blurb: An in-depth introduction to using the Magic: the Gathering color wheel as a psychological typing tool for individuals, groups, and projects.

title: NARRATIVEMANCY 101: WHY PAPER BEATS ROCK
name: paper
blurb: The first in (hopefully) a series of posts about using the power of narrative to teach, persuade, inspire, and explain. This entry attempts to provide a model for why narratives are so powerful, relative to personal experience and impersonal evidence.

title: NEED DYNAMICS
name: need
blurb: A discussion of three specific concepts relating to navigating neediness in interpersonal relationships.

title: THE LENGTH OF A THOUGHT
name: length
blurb: Presenting a contender for the replacement for "System 1" and "System 2," which, while useful, were never really real.

title: WRITING 102: GRACE
name: grace
blurb: A close look at a particular kind of experience in fiction, how to create it, and why it has an emotional impact on the audience.

title: EDUC 103: ANTAGONISTIC LEARNING
name: educ103
blurb: The third in an ongoing series of education/pedagogy posts.  This one is about the teacher-student relationshipâ€”in particular, a model which is overrepresented in fiction, and underrepresented in real, everyday classrooms.

title: THE LEVERS OF THE SOUL
name: lever
blurb: Thinking about the ways in which I move myself, and the levers that let me do it.

title: VOLUNTARY EFFORT
name: volunteer
blurb: An explicit, generalized model of how to motivate others, drawing on insights about motivating myself.

title: WINNING THE HUMAN RACE
name: map
blurb: A Rationality 101 post, drawing on the common framing of the external universe as the "territory" and one's personal understanding of it as the "map."

title: EDUC 102: ECONOMICS
name: educ102
blurb: The second in an ongoing series of education/pedagogy posts.  This one is about refining and defending an economic model of classroom management.

title: FLAVORFUL EFFORT
name: flavor
blurb: An examination of positive and negative flavorings in making and executing plans, and an attempt to define the right places for each.

title: EDUC 101: AXIOMS
name: educ101
blurb: The first of a long series of posts explaining my thoughts on the purpose of education, the nature of the student-teacher relationship, and the problems with modern Western pedagogy.

title: QUITTABILITY
name: quittability
blurb: An attempt to identify an underlying principle connecting various failure modes, especially in the realm of "Screw this; I quit."

title: PRIME DIRECTIVE
name: federation
blurb: In which the only stable time loop that includes a Federation must also include a Prime Directive.

title: BLACK & WHITE
name: twokinds
blurb: A short poem written after a personal lesson on the value of being less judgmental.

title: JUCANTE SPOILER ARTICLE
name: spoiler
blurb: In 2013 and 2014, my friends and I designed a complete Magic: The Gathering expansion of over 250 cards.  In the fall of 2014, as I began to consider an application to work for Wizards of the Coast, I wrote the following "spoiler article" mimicking the style of the articles published on the Wizards website before a new expansion is released.

title: FANTASY WITH A PURPOSE
name: potter
blurb: My cousin Bridget is a linguist and etymologist who writes a blog about language and literature.  When she put out a general call for guest posts for a Harry Potter theme week, I said yes before I even had a topic in mind.

title: NEVER AGAIN
name: never
blurb: During my time at the University of North Carolina, I took a creative writing course from the outstanding Lawrence Naumoff.  This was one of my favorite assignments during that course, in which we were to make use of absolutely every element of a given photograph as we wrote a short story inspired by it.  I would later use the same assignment with my sixth grade students.

title: BFF
name: bff
blurb: This one's going to have to speak for itself.  At the start of Professor Naumoff's class, he explicitly told us to go ahead and forget about getting an A, and I publicly challenged him on it, and he essentially washed his hands of responsibility for my future disappointment.  This was my final project, which earned a 95.

title: CORE CONNECTIONS GUIDE
name: handbook
blurb: At the end of my three-year stint teaching sixth-grade Creative Productions at Voyager Academy (later renamed to Core Connections), I wrote the following handbook to summarize my style, method, content, and rationale for the teacher replacing me.

title: WHAT 100 REALLY MEANS
blurb: This is one of many, many, MANY pieces of writing I did on the subject of parkour philosophy and method between 2003 and 2009, during the "forum days."  It serves as a good example of the length, quality, style, and theme of most of my posts on 3run.co.uk and parkour.net, which made my nom-de-plume "TK17" an internationally-recognized name in the community.

title: INSTRUCTIONS
name: instructions
blurb: There is a Neil Gaiman poem titled "Instructions" that offers a set of handy rules for people navigating their way through a fairy tale.  When I read it, I shed a few tears, but it was also missing many of the lessons I'd learned from Narnia, Redwall, the Castle in the Attic, the Minpins, the Sea of Stories, and all the other tales of my youth.  This is my more complete take.

title: TIME-BOUND PROGRAMS
name: timebound
blurb: A significant part of my work at the Seattle parkour gym was developing and organizing curriculum.  We often offered special sessions and seminars ranging from a single day to twenty or thirty sessions.  This is a guide that was written to help coaches cover all the bases in time-bound programs of various lengths.

title: RISK & LIABILITY
name: legal
blurb: While running an afterschool parkour club at Voyager Academy, and later while preparing to start a parkour gym in North Carolina, I discovered that there were not yet any standardized forms for parkour, as there are for more well-established activities like martial arts or gymnastics.  I created these for my own use in the meantime.

title: UNIT PLAN (6th GRADE)
name: unit
blurb: The following fifty-page document is the very first formal unit plan I ever wrote, used in the spring of 2009 with sixth graders during my student teaching at Gravelly Hill Middle School in North Carolina.  The unit focused on short fiction and involved reading, analysis, and writing; I would eventually teach a similar unit in my own Creative Productions classroom.

title: DETERMINISTIC MORALITY
name: freewill
blurb: As a teacherâ€”first of Tae Kwon Do, then of sixth graders, and finally of parkourâ€”I have often found that one of my most useful skills is the ability to rephrase and explain complex concepts.  That's the skill I was practicing in the following paper, completed for a Philosophy 101 class at the University of North Carolina.

title: ORPHANED PRINCE
name: telemachos
blurb: While a student at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, I took a class titled "Epic and Tragedy," in which we read many Greek and Roman writings in unabridged translations.  This was one of my better analyses during that semester, of the arc and motivations of Telemachos, son of Odysseus.

title: STREET SKITâ€”2ND DAN
name: streetskit
blurb: This is the introductory narration for the "street skit" section of my 2004 second-dan black belt test at Lee Brothers Tae Kwon Do in North Carolina.  The monologue was written by me and recorded by Professor Miller of NCSSM.  The accompanying music is "Hummel Gets The Rockets," from the soundtrack to "The Rock," by Hans Zimmer and Harry Gregson-Williams.

title: BEGINNINGS OF AN AVALANCHE
name: whatif
blurb: In my junior and senior years of high school, I attended the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics.  There, I took a class titled "Wisdom, Revelation, Reason, and Doubt," which was a more creative take on Western Civ.  The following was a "what if?" assignment completed for that class in which we were asked to make a small change to history and follow it to its logical conclusion.

title: TO JUDGE BETWEEN DREAMS
name: sword
blurb: I often allowed my enthusiasm to run away with me, especially in classes where the content was particularly engaging.  This piece, written for WRRD class at Science and Math, was intended to be a 3-5 page short story that accurately showcased historical details from medieval Europe.  I began in the early afternoon with a noble blacksmith, and ended up finishing at 3AM with seventeen pages.
